title: If magic is indistinguishable from technology, is technology also indistinguishable from magic as well, are they both exactly the same thing, or do we simply call them magic and technology because we don't know what else to call them? - Quora

response.answer_text: You’re mistaken when you state that neither magic nor technology are distinguishable from one another… they are two completely different things. You may be thinking of Arthur C. Clarke’s “Laws”: When a distinguished but elderly scientist states that something is possible, they are almost certainly right. When they state that something is impossible, they are very probably wrong.The only way of discovering the limits of the possible is to venture a little way past them into the impossible.Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.That third one may be what you’re thinking of. Much of what we know and understand today used to be ascribed to gods. Thunder? That was the gods bowling in heaven. Lightning? Zeus was angry at mortals, so he was hurling bolts to punish them. The path of the sun across the sky? It was being pulled behind a big chariot. If you demonstrated a lighter to a caveman, you would amaze and frighten him. Who can create fire in their hands?!? If you pumped music from an MP3 player into a bluetooth speaker in the days of the Renaissance, Shakespeare himself would call it miraculous. Music without any instruments! Medical science is a great example — we can fix and heal things that would have caused certain death just a few years ago. We’ve managed to leave the planet. We’ve put men on the moon. If you don’t understand something that’s going on (or the technology behind it), it may well look like “magic” to you.

Technology is the result of human invention, innovation and generally based upon accepted and understood principles. Magic (in terms of mysticism) appeals to a spiritual/supernatural understanding of the ‘way the Cosmos’ is. Perhaps Technology is based on that which is rational, demonstrable and accepted. Magic is subjective, not demonstrable in any consistent way and not widely accepted. Technology is chalk - useable, transferable and tangible which supports interaction with the physical Magick is smoke - nebulous, not easily graspable and apparently clouds interaction with the physical. Technology is the realm of the rational and objective. Magic is the realm of the mystical and spiritual. If advanced technology looks like magic, it is still technology even if of a type we don’t understand (yet)… Magic is a system of beliefs and practices by definition sitting outside of the realm of science.
